awd_titl_txt: Scalable Manufacturing of Hierarchical Silicon/Carbon Nanocomposite Anodes for Next Generation Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
Silicon has played a critical role in the modern world economy, particularly through its prominent role in the semiconductor industry. Silicon also has the potential to revolutionize the energy storage industry because it is one of the most promising anode materials for next-generation lithium-ion batteries. However, well-designed silicon anodes often require elaborated synthesis methods requiring the use of toxic chemicals, making it difficult to embrace these methods for widespread applications of silicon anodes. This award will address this deficiency by investigating a novel, simple and scalable nanomanufacturing method to produce silicon anodes with well-designed hierarchical structures at low cost and with no involvement of toxic chemicals. The research work leads to a nanomanufacturing method that is scalable at industry level and that can fabricate silicon/carbon nanocomposites with well-designed internal structures and unprecedented performance for next-generation lithium-ion batteries. The availability of new anode materials paves the way to enable broad market penetration of electric vehicles, extend cell phone working hours to multiple days before recharging, broaden the application areas of batteries including military usage, and make the technology greener and more energy efficient. The project offers undergraduate students opportunities to participate in research through a semester long Inter-professional Project. Presentations on "Roles of Chemistry in Lithium-ion Batteries" with hands-on demonstrations are planned in the science classes of high schools with high percentage of under-represented minority students. These activities are designed to inspire high school stucents to pursue careers in science, engineering and technology.

This project is the first to investigate a simple and scalable nanomanufacturing method that can fabricate Si anodes with a well-designed hierarchical structure that combines features of nanoscale Si building-blocks, conductive coatings and engineered void space plus in-situ formation of graphene. This well-engineered hierarchical structure offers Si anodes with large specific-capacity, high specific power and long cycle life as well as high areal capacity. This nanomanufacturing method starts with commercially available micron-sized Si and graphite particles, which are subjected to high-energy ball milling during which graphene is produced in situ. The entire nanomanufacturing process and powder handling is carried out in ambient environment except during the high-energy ball milling and carbon coating processes, making this nanomanufacturing method easily scalable at industrial levels. The project leads to a nanomanufacturing method to fabricate hierarchical silicon/carbon nanocomposite anodes with unprecedented properties and performance at low cost and without the use of toxic chemicals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF project, we have established a facile, environmentally benign, industrially scalable, and low-cost method to fabricate Si@void@C micro-reactor particles that can exhibit high specific capacity, high power and long cycle life simultaneously for Li-ion batteries. Our novel synthesis method is composed of three major steps: (1) high-energy ball milling that breaks down micron-sized Si particles to submicron-sized particles with nano-grains (i.e., forming nanostructured Si particles), (2) carbonization process that embeds submicron-sized nanostructured Si particles in a porous carbon framework, and (3) NaOH etching treatment to introduce engineered voids with nano-channel morphology inside the carbon-encapsulated nanostructured Si core, leading to the formation of Si@void@C particles. Each of these Si@void@C particles with sizes ranging from 0.1 to ~1.0 mm serves as a micro-reactor to accommodate the volume expansion and shrinkage within the micro-reactor during lithiation and delithiation without inducing much volume change of the micro-reactor itself, while the outer carbon framework offers high electronic conductivity. Equally important, the nano-channel voids inside Si@void@C particles also permit fast Li ion transport inside the micro-reactor so that fast charging can be done without Li plating. The Si@void@C anodes can deliver a specific capacity per gram of Si@void@C at 700 mAh/g and a specific capacity of 560 mAh/g at the electrode level (including the weights of carbon black and PAA binder. This electrode-level specific capacity is 74% higher than that provided by the state-of-the-art graphite anodes. Thus, Si@void@C anodes have a great potential to replace the state-of-the-art graphite anodes for next-generation Li-ion batteries in the near future.

            Due to the outstanding properties of Si@void@C micro-reactor particles and industrially scalable and low-cost method in fabricating Si@void@C at scale, non-provisional patent applications in three regions worldwide (United States, European Regions, and China) have been filed. These non-provisional patent applications give Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) the ownership for Si@void@C-based Li-ion batteries, paving the way for translating scientific discoveries in the lab to technology transfer in a timely manner. In the duration of this NSF project, five PhD students have been trained and worked on this project at different stages of research. Among these 5 PhD students, two are female students. Further, opportunities have been provided to these students for them to work with researchers at Argonne National Laboratory via the DOE General User Facilities program and the NSF Supplemental INTERN Funding program. In addition to the research training and education for graduate students, we are also active in outreach to middle/high school teachers and students. In the summers of 2017, 2018 and 2019 we worked with ASM International Chicago Chapter in hosting "Materials Camps" for high/middle school teachers. There were about 15 to 20 teachers participating in each of these "Materials Camps" every summer. Our research group also regularly presented hands-on demonstrations to prospective students and their parents to inspire them to pursue STEM careers. In 2021 (the last year of this NSF project), we participated in "Science Cafe" activities, hosting ~28 student from Mahalia Jackson School and Learn Charter School and ~40 students from De LaSalle High (all are minority serving schools) and showing them how to fabricate Li-ion batteries.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Leon L Shaw
